com.reactivecascade.i.reactive

Interface IReactiveTarget<IN>

  • Type Parameters:
    IN - the type of value expected as input to this node. If this is the head of the reactive chain, it is the same type as SOURCE.
    All Superinterfaces:
    INamed
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    PersistentValue, ReactiveImageView, ReactiveInteger, ReactiveLong, ReactiveValue, Subscription

    public interface IReactiveTarget<IN>
extends INamed
    An object which can receive repeated value assertions from a reactive functional chain.

    Commonly used default implementations are Subscription and ReactiveValue.

    Note that classes which are functional but not reactive only receive a value one time before becoming immutable value object. These are thus _not_ IReactiveTargets because the 2nd etc firing would not be meaningful. You will see example of these in the package com.reactivecascade.i.functional

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void fire(IN in)
      An upchain IReactiveSource is notifying us of a new input value to process.
      void fireNext(IN in)
      Same as fire(Object) however this is queued LIFO for more immediate execution.
      void subscribeSource(java.lang.String reason, IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
      Notification that an IReactiveSource will start sending updates This allows the target which is responsible for holding a strong reference to the source to prevent it from being garbage collected until all targets of a given source go out of scope and are themselves garbage collected.
      void unsubscribeAllSources(java.lang.String reason)
      Remove all up-chain branches from this node of the reactive function tree
      void unsubscribeSource(java.lang.String reason, IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
      Notification that an IReactiveSource will no longer send updates Since this target is responsible for holding a reference to the source to keep it from being garbage collected, this target can not forget the source and, if not used elsewhere, it can be garbage collected.

      • Methods inherited from interface com.reactivecascade.i.INamed

        getName

    • Method Detail

      • fire

        void fire(IN in)
        An upchain IReactiveSource is notifying us of a new input value to process. You don't usually call the fire methods directly. They are called for you when this is an input or state change, for example by ReactiveValue.set(Object)

        Nodes within a reactive chain may choose to be stateless such as Subscription.

        Nodes at the leaf of a reactive chain will typically retain this value as state, for example (ReactiveValue).

        They may also choose to otherwise create a stateful side effect with the value received. The recommended practice is to not create such side effects except in the leaf node(s) at the end of chain branches. If you violate this rule, be warned you tend to end up with a hairy memory management and partially-completed-stateful-logic-before-exception error correction mess.

        If you would like to unlink this object when the fire operation results in an error, you must do so in an .onError() statement lower down in the chain you wish to trigger such an action.

        Parameters:
        in - The value from the previous link in the reactive chain.

      • fireNext

        void fireNext(IN in)
        Same as fire(Object) however this is queued LIFO for more immediate execution. You do not generally call this directly. Chains call this for you. It is called instead of fire(Object) mid-chain to reduce work in progress and complete the task tree is an depth-first manner. This reduces the latency of individual chains once execution starts. It also decreases the peak memory load by more rapidly flushing intermediate values to the leaf node side effects of the chain.
        Parameters:
        in -

      • subscribeSource

        void subscribeSource(java.lang.String reason,
                     IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will start sending updates This allows the target which is responsible for holding a strong reference to the source to prevent it from being garbage collected until all targets of a given source go out of scope and are themselves garbage collected. You may manually speed this process by calling unsubscribeSource(String, IReactiveSource), however if you choose not to or forget to do so, it will be taken care of for you fairly soon.
        Parameters:
        reactiveSource -

      • unsubscribeSource

        void unsubscribeSource(java.lang.String reason,
                       IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will no longer send updates Since this target is responsible for holding a reference to the source to keep it from being garbage collected, this target can not forget the source and, if not used elsewhere, it can be garbage collected.
        Parameters:
        reason -
        reactiveSource -

      • unsubscribeAllSources

        void unsubscribeAllSources(java.lang.String reason)
        Remove all up-chain branches from this node of the reactive function tree
